text: the science fiction radio show a commentary on science fiction today presented by the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association this is David Cruz and David Carson On this program, we will be talking with author Larry Niven. Niven first appeared in print in 1964, and by 1976, he had won the Hugo Award five times. He has written a set of stories set in what he calls Known Space, which are a future history or a series of stories with a common background. He has also written several novels and stories not related to the Known Space series. Aside from science fiction, Niven has written a fantasy called The Magic Goes Away and co-authored with Jerry Purnell a science fiction rendering of Dante's Inferno entitled, appropriately enough, Inferno. Other collaborations with Jerry Purnell include A Moat in God's Eye and the bestseller Lucifer's Hammer. For my first question to you, Mr. Niven, I'd like to ask if you classify yourself as a hard science fiction writer in the tradition of Hal Clement? If you've got to classify me, that's where I sit, yes. would I suppose all writers resist classification as best they can I do other things too fantasy considerable fantasy a great deal more hard science fiction not much in the way of soft science fiction articles speeches I'm the guy who did a study of the medical problems of breeding Kryptonians, called Man of Steel, Woman of Kleenex. And I just published the only venture I've ever made into economics, a method which would also solve the problem of nuclear waste disposal. The idea is to turn the nuclear waste into coins. A healthy economy is one in which the money circulates fast. You mentioned that you had not written much in the area of soft science fiction. Do you think the New Wave is past, that fans and writers are turning back to strongly science-oriented stories? Yes, I do. However, the New Wave was very good to me. When I was first getting started, I was the only new hard science fiction writer. The New Wave is a very persuasive thing and very easy to use to justify bad stories. I think that's what killed it. Not that increased characterization and experiments with typography and story format are a bad thing in themselves, but it's so easy to use New Wave to justify a bad story. It was bound to collapse. How did you begin writing science fiction? Were you always a science fiction reader, a fan? Yes. And presently I found I was making up... I was daydreaming stories that seemed worth writing. Did you tell the stories to others before you gained enough confidence to write them down? Yes, I've been a storyteller all my life. You have a large and involved fan following. Do you ever write specifically for them or do you write only how you want to? I mostly write for myself for an imaginary reader who resembles me a great deal. Only he needs things explained to him. Beyond that, I sell it where I can and pick up readers where I can. Let's turn to your known space series for a moment. How did you get started writing a future history? Well, there had been future histories around. Poole Anderson and Robert Heinlein. And I tell you, I guess we each evolve the idea somewhat independently, and the idea is that if you carved out a consistent workable future, it seems a shame to waste it on one story. You put in the background because you want the background of a story to seem bigger than it is, so there are things that are simply unexplained. And if you think of more to say on a given subject, why, you go with it. And if you think of a story that fits into the background of a previous story and allows you to elaborate on that background, sometimes you fall in love with the background, and presently you've got a bunch of stories that link. In the afterword of Ringworld Engineers you said that your known space series was completed. Is that still true, and if so, why? I've given up saying that the that the Known Space series is dead there's just no point in it I've written five books worth of Known Space stories since I said that and besides that I have no doubt that I'll come up with stories set in Gildly Arms time I like writing science fiction detective stories it's just hard work I do not have a detective story in my head It'll have to emerge. But that's the beginning of known space, and I'll continue to work with it where it looks like fun. You have, as you mentioned, written science fiction detective stories, and you've experimented with humor in science fiction. Is there any subject area that you think can't be handled well in the science fiction genre? No, I can't think of any. I guess I go along with the idea that there are these interlocked circles to represent various areas of fiction, and they all swim in the sea of fantasy. Science fiction probably includes the entire portion of fantasy that is possible. And mainstream would be somewhere in there. Nurse novels would be somewhere in that. There would be no subject you could treat in English that couldn't be treated in a science fiction format except fantasy and that would be treated in a fantasy format. Probably your best known work in the known space series is Ringworld. Can you tell us how that concept came about? Oh, I ran across the concept Dyson sphere. Dyson the mathematician came up with the concept Dyson shell, and he was misunderstood to some extent, so presently I ran across an article about Dyson spheres. Picture that as a golf ball 93 million miles in radius with a sun at the center and gravity generators all around the outside so you would live on the inside, terraform it with oceans and soil and air. I ran across that and I didn't like it. I thought it could be improved, and I wound up with the ringworld. Freeman Dyson, in commenting on your adaptation of his idea, said that a great number of small ringworlds would be better than the large one that you had. I believe I gave an acceptable answer to that, in the ring world engineers but in general he'd be right it's just that the ring world engineers in particular are people who like defendable weapons of huge size many of your fans pointed out a number of mistakes and made many elaborations on the concept of the ring world can you tell us what some of them were and how they were corrected or worked into the sequel For instance, I suspected the ring world was unstable, and I suspected you'd need attitude jets. I was sure that the ring world was spinning fast enough to permit bizarre dram jets to be used as attitude jets, which means you don't have a fuel problem at all. You're burning the solar wind. But rapidly, some MIT people demonstrated that the ring world was unstable, and they were chanting it in the halls at the Next Worldcon. the ring world is unstable the ring world is unstable ah it still took about seven years for anyone to figure out the exact numbers for the instability and they are horrifying the ring world a major solar flare would have the ring world grinding against its sun in five years well i worked in the plot that was one uh elaboration or error. Another just can't be correct. It seems that there's too much twilight with the shadow squares set up the way I have them set up. You get too much of neither day nor night but twilight, half the sun showing, part of the sun showing. The shadow squares ought to be set up with about five big shadow squares moving in a retrograde world. That way you get day and night setting Much faster When it sets Terminator line moves like a bat out of hell It's still a little fuzzy But it doesn't matter Third point Somebody pointed out That the tensile strength Necessary To hold the ring rule together Is on the order of the tensile strength Of an atomic nucleus It's the super strong force Okay, I can live with that. I can postulate that. I knew scales would have to be stronger than any normal material already. already. A high school class in Florida got to work on the ringworld, and their conclusion was that the ringworld's worst problem is that all the topsoil would wind up in the oceans in about 3,000 years. There are no earthquakes on the ringworld, no mountain-building Okay, that's a tough one, I set up a spill pipe system that runs the Top, runs the sea bottom muck from the sea bottom under the ring world and up over the edge of the ring rim wall that even allows you some, some minds accumulation of useful metals, what else? Well, I'm checking in my head. I find Frank Gasparak's suggestion that a machine-building culture on the ring world, which reached our level, wouldn't have any petroleum products to use. They would wind up using alcohol, where we use gasoline. And fine, I can live with that. As a matter of fact, the sludge from making alcohol for automobiles, the sludge can be used to make plastics, maybe. Plastic-like substances, maybe. The chemicals are just as elaborate as the residues from petroleum. What else? Still checking in my head. I pick up on other things I can't use, such as Dan Alderson's solar system which involves four ring worlds. He's got three ring worlds about the size of mine, rotating orthogonally on frictionless bearings. And the fourth ring world is about the size of the orbit of Jupiter and inhabited by Mesclanites. Mesclanites derived from a novel by Hauer Klemmann, Mission of Gravity. and mesclunites require cold temperatures about those of the orbit of Jupiter, as opposed to Jupiter, which has an internal heat source. Cold temperatures and heavy gravity. So his fourth ring world is the size of the orbit of Jupiter and spinning like a bat out of hell. I had it figured out that if they spun that ring world any faster, it would get nearer the speed of light and contract, Dan says I've misunderstood relativity, it would not contract. Okay, I still haven't figured out why not. Well, you obviously enjoy playing the game, as how Clement calls it, between your own scientific knowledge and that of your readers and peers. Absolutely. I incorporated everything that sounded good that I could use in elaborating the design of the ringworld. What do you think about the current ideas for space habitats that are proposed by Gerard Evel and others. I think they are grandiose, and I certainly wouldn't stop them. But the space program seems to have fallen flat on its face at this point. We will have trouble reaching the moon again. Getting back to the moon is as big a problem as we can face. I resent having to say that, but I believe it's true. Let's turn for a moment to another of your novels, One written with Jerry Pernell. The Moat in God's Eye. How do you go about constructing an alien like the Moatis? Were you influenced by anyone in that area? The Moatis was, no. Not in that case. In that case, I had the idea that I was following a progression with a protozoan, with an amoeba. You get radio symmetry inside and out. Move up a goodly distance and you find starfishes with radial symmetry on the outside and bilateral symmetry on the inside. Move up a little further, you find flatworms and worms of all states. At the level of bilateral symmetry inside and out, go as far as a human, you find bilateral symmetry on the outside and no symmetry, well, half symmetrical on the inside. The lungs look symmetrical, the kidneys look symmetrical. The intestines look like somebody dropped a plate of spaghetti. I tried to move on to the next step Bilaterally unsymmetrical on my outside And I got the original Modi, which was the engineered for us But I always design aliens For themselves. I almost never design an alien to match a story the story the story, some story will eventually include the aliens. The alien stands for himself. I think that one of the outstanding aspects of the motties was their non-use of standardized machines. They would create whatever replacement parts that they needed on the spot. Do you recall what caused you to think along those lines for your alien society? I was just playing along. I was just playing with ideas at that point. and that one seemed like a fun one. It also seemed likely enough, if you've got a critter with not much intelligence except in the direction of tool making and tool altering, then why not? The thing has to keep testing its ability, or it will lose it. It might as well be designing something every time it needs a specific machine. a master can always stop it and have it producing as if by assembly line if a master needs a lot of somethings fast. In Ring World, you developed something called the T. LeBron gene, humans bred to be lucky. Was that just a story gimmick, or were you extrapolating on the evolution of humanity? Oh, partly that, and partly you've got to remember the time I was writing. I was damn sick and tired of psychic powers showing up in stories. I did not believe in psychic powers at that time. I've been told they look pretty good now. But at the time, I conceived the T. Labrum gene as being the ultimate psychic power, which you may interpret either as luck or as author control. and in that sense it was something of a put-on except that i can believe almost anything while i'm writing the story and i am able to extrapolate so if tila brown is lucky certain things emerge and if she's just a statistical fluke then then something else emerges and that's that People will interpret anything that happens to them as lucky. Defending their preconception. What do you consider to be your best work or your favorite work? No, I couldn't tell you that. There is no way I can name a favorite work. The whole, my career is a progression for one thing. Take any novel or any important short story even out of that progression and it wanders away in a different direction. So I don't think I have a favorite story, but I suppose I can name In Constant Moon, which is virtually the only strictly love story I've ever done. And I suppose I could name Lucifer's Hammer, which made me the most money. Though Emoting God's Eye may beat that. I suppose I could name, oh, Man of Steel, Woman of Kleenex, which has gotten me the most laughs, I suppose. Everybody seems to have read it, and those who haven't have heard about it a cocktail party. Or what? Jerry Pornell and I just recently wrote the last ten minutes for a movie that had a good 90 minutes followed by a bad last 10 minutes. And the last I've heard is they're not going to make the movie, which is a dirty shame. That is, they're not going to make the last 10 minutes an hour away. They're going to fiddle with what they've got. And that's a really dirty shame. What they've got is garbage. I really hope they use that last 10 minutes. And if they do, I will get considerable enjoyment out of that. And that'll be my favorite. You name it. You mentioned your collaboration with Jerry Parnell. Which do you prefer, writing alone or with another author? I prefer variety. I even prefer variety and my collaborators. I just finished a novel with a Stephen Barnes, and we're starting another, a short one. And Jerry and I are starting another, almost instantly, novel about… Well, we've designed an alien that could invade the earth and also would want to. It's tough to get an alien whom you could believe would want to invade the earth from another star, considering the distances involved and the energies involved and the penalties for failure and the lack of, uh, the unlikelihood that it will do your home planet any good if you conquer something that is six light years away. Anyway, we've designed one, and we will be writing a novel about that. When writing in collaboration, is it difficult to decide who writes what? Hard sometimes, but it always resolves. The question is, Who is most qualified to write a given scene that we have both decided needs writing? Before we start, we have the novel all laid out. We know what's going in virtually everywhere. And if we don't, it feels like we do. And if we find out we don't, we elaborate as we get to that section. Okay, the next question is, Who is qualified to write a given scene? Sometimes it's obvious. If we're dealing with a madman, he's mine. If we're dealing with military operations, it's Jerry's. Aliens are generally mine. Politics is generally Jerry's. Knowledge of history is generally Jerry's. And a real evil son of a bitch, Jerry usually creates him, and I usually run with him afterward. because Jerry has a lot of textbooks on psychology and a PhD in psychology for that matter sorry doctorate in psychology and when he's created a really evil son of a bitch he just hates him too much to work with him I can usually do something Horace Barry went that way and the rapist in Lucifer's Hammer and a couple of the characters in Inferno I understand that both you and Mr. Pennell use computer word processors. How does that aid in your writing? It makes first draft a little faster. But it makes corrections enormously faster. You get a more polished novel when I'm using a word processor. Polishing is just like thinking into the machine almost. The word processor behaves like a magic typewriter. it does everything you would want a typewriter to do, only it can. It can't erase whole blocks of print at a time, and then straighten up the page so it looks like you never made any corrections. But a word processor can do just that, and move blocks up and down the page. Up and down the manuscript. What do you think, Mr. Nimmin, is the future of science fiction? Has fantasy begun taking over, or is there a lot more hard science fiction to come? Hard to say. For one thing, writers in general don't take orders worth a damn. The science-fiction field is galloping off in all directions just as it always has, and the reader will make the final decision in most cases. What will be successful will depend on who buys what book. That's always been true. I understand that some of your works were involved several years ago with the animated Star Trek series. How did that come about? Oh, it went like this. They were going to start a Star Trek cartoon, and the lady who was story editor got me involved. I tried to give them a story that involved a mini black hole and an outsider ship. I had the idea that Star Trek had been using men in rubber suits for so long that they wouldn't realize how much more freedom they had with the animated version. That turns out not to be the case. They had some very good aliens in there. But that story turned out to be a little over the heads of their intended audience. so I want it did incidentally wind up as the first version of the last part of a story called The Borderlands of Soul so I eventually wound up meeting Gene Roddenberry and he wound up suggesting why don't I take a story called The Soft Weapon and turn it into a Star Trek version and I did that and called it The Slaver Weapon and fine they eventually made a cartoon out of it they also sold the right to turn that cartoon script into a story. They sold that to Ballantyne. I got mildly upset the president of the CIFU who was Jerry Bornell at the time got seriously upset and started making as many ways as he could and what eventually happened was that they sent me a dollar for a check for two dollars and something something cents somewhere between two and three dollars and jerry i don't know where the negotiations went but jerry wound up saying okay that defends the principle of the thing uh we'll ask for more next time and that's that for some years by by then i had written to ballantyne and gotten a letter from Betty Ballantine saying, hey, we won't ever use it. We promise. We see you're upset. We promise we won't ever do anything with this. A little later, the Ballantines got out of the Valentine Books business and into the business of printing illustrated stuff, and Judy Lindell Ray wound up in charge, and presently, presently, I'm being offered $2,000 as advisor to Alan Dean Foster who will turn my script into a novel. And I said fine when what I really meant was acceptable. A few months later I've got a letter from Judy Lin dropping the price to $500 and I pulled my top. I said A. I won't collaborate with with you or Alan on anything of the kind. And B. You may not use anything from known space except what's in the script. and that is the way it happens. Are there any plans for motion picture or television adaptations of any of your works in the near future? Yes, there are. I just don't know how far they are going to go but there is a group that owns an option on Death by Ecstasy and a guy who owns an option on The Mode in God's Eye and, let's see, I've got a friend trying to get a public broadcasting system to make a TV version of Incontent Women, which would be nice, all of which would be nice. Are there any contemporary writers that you particularly enjoy reading? Yes, a great many. Ursula Le Guin, John Varley, Phu Anderson, Jerry Pournell. How far do we go with this? I like the old ones, and I like the new ones. I like about half of uh, Colin Ellison's stories, which is a better record than... many writers have. I like a few of Bill Dix's stories, and I will probably buy the last of the Dorcy books by Gordy Dixson. In fact, it's damn certain I will read it I'll buy it if it doesn't come free I'm swamped in free books I'm a Piers Anthony fan I don't know how numerous we Piers Anthony fans are I like the puzzles in his books And his books are always jammed with puzzles And new ways of thinking And so forth One last question I don't suppose those Pearson Puppeteers ever stuck you the formula for the General Products whole, did they? No, I don't have the formula in the General Products whole. But I have reason to suspect that there are puppeteers on Earth. Look at their characteristics. Forget the shape. They must be masters of biology to hide that peculiar three-legged, two-headed shape. But consider their characteristics. They are cowards. that is, they want everything utterly safe no corners on anything, everything is soft surfaces around the puppeteer world they don't even keep their world near a sun regarding it as a runaway fusion reactor which of course it is so, desperate regard for safety plus an urge to meddle in the lifestyle of other species driving urge to middle with practically no restraints attached. What does that remind you of? It seems nearly certain to me that Ralph Nader is a Pearson's book in here. This is David Cruz. I'm David Carson. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, a presentation of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association in conjunction with KOCV-FM and Odessa College, Odessa, Texas.

On this program, we will be talking with author Larry Niven.
Niven first appeared in print in 1964, and by 1976, he had won the Hugo Award five times.
He has written a set of stories set in what he calls Known Space,
which are a future history or a series of stories with a common background.
He has also written several novels and stories not related to the Known Space series.
Aside from science fiction, Niven has written a fantasy called The Magic Goes Away
and co-authored with Jerry Purnell a science fiction rendering of Dante's Inferno
entitled, appropriately enough, Inferno.
Other collaborations with Jerry Purnell include A Moat in God's Eye
and the bestseller Lucifer's Hammer.

as a hard science fiction writer in the tradition of Hal Clement?
If you've got to classify me, that's where I sit, yes.

Yes, I do. However, the New Wave was very good to me.

The New Wave is a very persuasive thing and very easy to use to justify bad stories.
I think that's what killed it.
Not that increased characterization
and experiments with typography and story format
are a bad thing in themselves,
but it's so easy to use New Wave to justify a bad story.
It was bound to collapse.

Yes.
And presently I found I was making up...

Yes, I've been a storyteller all my life.
You have a large and involved fan following.
Do you ever write specifically for them or do you write only how you want to?
I mostly write for myself for an imaginary reader who resembles me a great deal.
Only he needs things explained to him.
Beyond that, I sell it where I can and pick up readers where I can.
Let's turn to your known space series for a moment.
How did you get started writing a future history?
Well, there had been future histories around.
Poole Anderson and Robert Heinlein.
And I tell you, I guess we each evolve the idea somewhat independently,
and the idea is that if you carved out a consistent workable future,

Evel and others.
I think they are grandiose, and I certainly wouldn't stop them.

Not in that case.

And I got the original Modi, which was the engineered for us

For themselves. I almost never design an alien to match a story the story
the story, some story will eventually include the aliens.
The alien stands for himself.
I think that one of the outstanding aspects of the motties was their non-use of standardized
machines.
They would create whatever replacement parts that they needed on the spot.
Do you recall what caused you to think along those lines for your alien society?
I was just playing along.
I was just playing with ideas at that point.
and that one seemed like a fun one.
It also seemed likely enough,
if you've got a critter with not much intelligence
except in the direction of tool making and tool altering,
then why not?
The thing has to keep testing its ability,
or it will lose it.
It might as well be designing something
every time it needs a specific machine.
a master can always stop it and have it producing
as if by assembly line if a master needs a lot of somethings fast.
In Ring World, you developed something called the T. LeBron gene,
humans bred to be lucky.
Was that just a story gimmick, or were you extrapolating on the evolution of humanity?
Oh, partly that, and partly you've got to remember the time I was writing.
I was damn sick and tired of psychic powers showing up in stories.
I did not believe in psychic powers at that time.
I've been told they look pretty good now.
But at the time, I conceived the T. Labrum gene
as being the ultimate psychic power,
which you may interpret either as luck or as author control.
and in that sense it was something of a put-on except that i can believe almost anything while
i'm writing the story and i am able to extrapolate so if tila brown is lucky certain things emerge
and if she's just a statistical fluke then then something else emerges and that's that
People will interpret anything that happens to them as lucky.
Defending their preconception.
What do you consider to be your best work or your favorite work?
No, I couldn't tell you that.
There is no way I can name a favorite work.
The whole, my career is a progression for one thing.
Take any novel or any important short story even
out of that progression
and it wanders away in a different direction.
So I don't think I have a favorite story,
but I suppose I can name In Constant Moon,
which is virtually the only strictly love story I've ever done.
And I suppose I could name Lucifer's Hammer,
which made me the most money.
Though Emoting God's Eye may beat that.
I suppose I could name, oh, Man of Steel, Woman of Kleenex, which has gotten me the
most laughs, I suppose.
Everybody seems to have read it, and those who haven't have heard about it a cocktail
party.
Or what?
Jerry Pornell and I just recently wrote the last ten minutes for a movie that had a good
90 minutes followed by a bad last 10 minutes.
And the last I've heard is they're not going to make the movie,
which is a dirty shame. That is, they're not going to make the last 10 minutes
an hour away. They're going to fiddle with what they've got. And that's a really
dirty shame. What they've got is garbage.
I really hope they use that last
10 minutes. And if they do, I will get considerable enjoyment out of that.
And that'll be my favorite. You name it.
You mentioned your collaboration with Jerry Parnell.
Which do you prefer, writing alone or with another author?
I prefer variety.
I even prefer variety and my collaborators.
I just finished a novel with a Stephen Barnes, and we're starting another, a short one.
And Jerry and I are starting another, almost instantly, novel about…
Well, we've designed an alien that could invade the earth
and also would want to.
It's tough to get an alien whom you could believe
would want to invade the earth from another star,
considering the distances involved and the energies involved
and the penalties for failure
and the lack of, uh, the unlikelihood that it will do your home planet any good
if you conquer something that is six light years away.
Anyway, we've designed one, and we will be writing a novel about that.
When writing in collaboration, is it difficult to decide who writes what?
Hard sometimes, but it always resolves.
The question is, Who is most qualified to write a given scene that we have both decided needs writing?
Before we start, we have the novel all laid out.
We know what's going in virtually everywhere.
And if we don't, it feels like we do.
And if we find out we don't, we elaborate as we get to that section.
Okay, the next question is, Who is qualified to write a given scene?
Sometimes it's obvious.
If we're dealing with a madman, he's mine.
If we're dealing with military operations, it's Jerry's.
Aliens are generally mine.
Politics is generally Jerry's.
Knowledge of history is generally Jerry's.
And a real evil son of a bitch, Jerry usually creates him, and I usually run with him afterward.
because Jerry has a lot of textbooks on psychology
and a PhD in psychology for that matter
sorry doctorate in psychology
and when he's created a really evil son of a bitch
he just hates him too much to work with him
I can usually do something
Horace Barry went that way
and the rapist in Lucifer's Hammer
and a couple of the characters in Inferno
I understand that both you and Mr. Pennell use computer word processors.
How does that aid in your writing?
It makes first draft a little faster.
But it makes corrections enormously faster.
You get a more polished novel when I'm using a word processor.
Polishing is just like thinking into the machine almost.
The word processor behaves like a magic typewriter.
it does everything you would want a typewriter to do, only it can.
It can't erase whole blocks of print at a time,
and then straighten up the page so it looks like you never made any corrections.
But a word processor can do just that,
and move blocks up and down the page.
Up and down the manuscript.
What do you think, Mr. Nimmin, is the future of science fiction?
Has fantasy begun taking over, or is there a lot more hard science fiction to come?

Hard to say. For one thing, writers in general don't take orders worth a damn. The science-fiction field is galloping off in all directions just as it always has, and the reader will make the final decision in most cases. What will be successful will depend on who buys what book. That's always been true.
I understand that some of your works were involved several years ago
with the animated Star Trek series. How did that come about?
Oh, it went like this. They were going to start a Star Trek cartoon,
and the lady who was story editor got me involved.
I tried to give them a story that involved a mini black hole and an outsider ship.
I had the idea that Star Trek had been using men in rubber suits for so long
that they wouldn't realize how much more freedom they had with the animated version.
That turns out not to be the case.
They had some very good aliens in there.
But that story turned out to be a little over the heads of their intended audience.
so
I want
it did incidentally
wind up as
the first version
of the
last part
of a story
called
The Borderlands of Soul
so I eventually
wound up
meeting Gene Roddenberry
and he wound up
suggesting
why don't I
take a story
called
The Soft Weapon
and turn it
into a
Star Trek version
and I did that
and called it
The Slaver Weapon
and
fine they eventually made a cartoon
out of it they also sold
the right to turn that
cartoon script
into a story. They sold that to
Ballantyne.
I got mildly upset
the president of the CIFU
who was Jerry Bornell at the time got
seriously upset
and started making as many ways as he could
and what eventually
happened was that they sent me a dollar
for a check for two dollars and something something cents somewhere between two and three
dollars and jerry i don't know where the negotiations went but jerry wound up saying
okay that defends the principle of the thing uh we'll ask for more next time
and that's that for some years by by then i had written to ballantyne and gotten a letter
from Betty Ballantine saying,
hey, we won't ever use it.
We promise.
We see you're upset.
We promise we won't ever do anything with this.
A little later,
the Ballantines got out of
the Valentine Books business
and into the business
of printing illustrated stuff,
and Judy Lindell Ray wound up in charge,
and presently,
presently, I'm being offered
$2,000 as advisor
to Alan Dean Foster
who will turn my script into a novel.
And
I said fine
when what I really meant was acceptable.
A few months later
I've got a letter from Judy Lin
dropping the price to $500 and I pulled my top.
I said A. I won't
collaborate with
with you or Alan
on anything of the kind.
And B. You may not use anything
from known space except what's in the script.
and that is the way it happens.
Are there any plans for motion picture
or television adaptations of any of your works
in the near future?
Yes, there are.
I just don't know how far they are going to go
but there is a group that owns an option
on Death by Ecstasy
and a guy who owns an option
on The Mode in God's Eye
and, let's see,
I've got a friend trying to get a public broadcasting system
to make a TV version of Incontent Women,
which would be nice, all of which would be nice.
Are there any contemporary writers that you particularly enjoy reading?
Yes, a great many.
Ursula Le Guin, John Varley, Phu Anderson, Jerry Pournell.
How far do we go with this? I like the old ones, and I like the new ones. I like about half of uh,
Colin Ellison's stories, which is a better record than... many writers have.
I like a few of Bill Dix's stories, and I will probably buy the last of the Dorcy books by Gordy Dixson.
In fact, it's damn certain I will read it
I'll buy it if it doesn't come free
I'm swamped in free books
I'm a Piers Anthony fan
I don't know how numerous we Piers Anthony fans are
I like the puzzles in his books
And his books are always jammed with puzzles
And new ways of thinking
And so forth
One last question
I don't suppose those Pearson Puppeteers ever stuck you the formula for the General Products whole, did they?
No, I don't have the formula in the General Products whole.
But I have reason to suspect that there are puppeteers on Earth.
Look at their characteristics.
Forget the shape.
They must be masters of biology to hide that peculiar three-legged, two-headed shape.
But consider their characteristics.
They are cowards.
that is, they want everything utterly safe
no corners on anything, everything is soft surfaces around the puppeteer world
they don't even keep their world near a sun
regarding it as a runaway fusion reactor
which of course it is
so, desperate regard for safety
plus an urge to meddle in the lifestyle of other species
driving urge to middle
with practically no restraints attached.
What does that remind you of?
It seems nearly certain to me
that Ralph Nader is a Pearson's book in here.
This is David Cruz.
I'm David Carson.
